comment_text.mn11:1.1: Multiple suttas (eg. DN 8, DN 25, MN 12, AN 6.64, AN 9.11, and AN 10.21) invoke the indomitable force of the lion’s roar, the most mighty sound of the jungle (SN 22.78:1.2).
comment_text.mn11:2.1: The same teaching is given more briefly at AN 4.241:1.1, where the four ascetics are defined as the stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, and perfected one, and at DN 16:5.27.3, where the presence of the four ascetics is attributed to the practice of the eightfold path.
comment_text.mn11:3.2: Ko assāso kiṁ balaṁ is found only here and at MN 93:6.7, where it also deals with an unequivocal claim to superiority.
comment_text.mn11:3.11: This appears to be the only occurrence of sahadhammika in this sense in early Pali. Normally it has the sense “legitimate” (as eg. MN 90:5.4). The parallel at MA 103 has 同道.
comment_text.mn11:5.26: The topic of “proliferation” (papañca) is explored in MN 18.
comment_text.mn11:6.2: That is, the eternalists and the annihilationists.
comment_text.mn11:6.3: The sequence of operative terms here is allīna, upagata, ajjhosita. Normally allīna in Pali means to “stick to, cling to”. But read this passage compared to SN 12.15:2.5 where we find a similar movement of drawing close (upagata)and getting attached. The Mahāvastu in Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit features allīyati in the sense “approach”, “resort”. This lends a greater coherence to this passage.
comment_text.mn11:10.3: Renunciate orders such as the Jains abhorred sensual pleasures, while the meditations of Brahmanical rishis depended on letting go all pleasures of the flesh.
comment_text.mn11:11.3: Perhaps referring to those such as Dīghanakha who claimed to believe in nothing (MN 74:2.4).
comment_text.mn11:12.3: The teaching on not-self is what sets Buddhism apart from all other teachings.
comment_text.mn11:13.1: Elsewhere sammaggata (“rightly placed”) is an epithet of the Buddha or other well-practiced sages, where I translate as “rightly comported”.
comment_text.mn11:16.1: Grasping is fully understood only when its source is known. Here the Buddha begins a partial treatment of dependent origination, implicitly connecting this to his special doctrine of not-self.

root_text.mn11:16.1: Ime ca, bhikkhave, cattāro upādānā. Kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?
root_text.mn11:16.2: Ime cattāro upādānā taṇhānidānā taṇhāsamudayā taṇhājātikā taṇhāpabhavā.
root_text.mn11:16.3: Taṇhā cāyaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?
root_text.mn11:16.5: Vedanā cāyaṁ, bhikkhave, kiṁnidānā kiṁsamudayā kiṁjātikā kiṁpabhavā?

root_text.mn11:17.1: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno avijjā pahīnā hoti vijjā uppannā, so avijjāvirāgā vijjuppādā neva kāmupādānaṁ upādiyati, na diṭṭhupādānaṁ upādiyati, na sīlabbatupādānaṁ upādiyati, na attavādupādānaṁ upādiyati.
root_text.mn11:17.2: Anupādiyaṁ na paritassati, aparitassaṁ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
root_text.mn11:17.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
root_text.mn11:17.5: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn11:0.2: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
translation_text.mn11:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn11:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn11:2.1: “‘Only here is there a true ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic.
translation_text.mn11:2.2: Other sects are empty of ascetics.’
translation_text.mn11:2.3: This, mendicants, is how you should rightly roar your lion’s roar.
translation_text.mn11:3.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:
translation_text.mn11:3.2: ‘But what is the source of the venerables’ certainty and forcefulness that they say this?’
translation_text.mn11:3.6: ‘There are four things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. Seeing these things in ourselves we say that:
translation_text.mn11:3.7: “Only here is there a true ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic.
translation_text.mn11:3.8: Other sects are empty of ascetics.”
translation_text.mn11:3.10: We have confidence in the Teacher, we have confidence in the teaching, and we have fulfilled the precepts.
translation_text.mn11:3.11: And we have love and affection for those who share our path,
translation_text.mn11:4.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:
translation_text.mn11:4.2: ‘We too have confidence in the Teacher—our Teacher; we have confidence in the teaching—our teaching; and we have fulfilled the precepts—our precepts.
translation_text.mn11:4.3: And we have love and affection for those who share our path,
translation_text.mn11:4.5: What, then, is the difference between you and us?’
translation_text.mn11:5.2: ‘Well, reverends, is the goal one or many?’
translation_text.mn11:5.3: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:
translation_text.mn11:5.4: ‘The goal is one, reverends, not many.’
translation_text.mn11:5.5: ‘But is that goal for the greedy or for those free of greed?’
translation_text.mn11:5.6: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:
translation_text.mn11:5.7: ‘That goal is for those free of greed, not for the greedy.’
translation_text.mn11:5.8: ‘Is it for the hateful or those free of hate?’
translation_text.mn11:5.11: ‘Is it for the delusional or those free of delusion?’
translation_text.mn11:5.14: ‘Is it for those who crave or those rid of craving?’
translation_text.mn11:5.17: ‘Is it for those who have fuel for grasping or those who do not?’
translation_text.mn11:5.19: ‘It’s for those who do not have fuel for grasping.’
translation_text.mn11:5.20: ‘Is it for the knowledgeable or the ignorant?’
translation_text.mn11:5.23: ‘Is it for those who favor and oppose or for those who don’t favor and oppose?’
translation_text.mn11:5.25: ‘It’s for those who don’t favor and oppose.’
translation_text.mn11:5.26: ‘But is that goal for those who enjoy proliferation or for those who enjoy non-proliferation?’
translation_text.mn11:5.27: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:
translation_text.mn11:5.28: ‘It’s for those who enjoy non-proliferation, not for those who enjoy proliferation.’
translation_text.mn11:6.1: Mendicants, there are these two views:
translation_text.mn11:6.2: views favoring existence and views favoring nonexistence.
translation_text.mn11:6.3: Any ascetics or brahmins who resort to, draw near to, and cling to a view favoring existence will oppose a view favoring nonexistence.
translation_text.mn11:6.4: Any ascetics or brahmins who resort to, draw near to, and cling to a view favoring nonexistence will oppose a view favoring existence.
translation_text.mn11:7.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these two views’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re greedy, hateful, delusional, craving, grasping, and ignorant. They favor and oppose, and they enjoy proliferation.
translation_text.mn11:7.2: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
translation_text.mn11:7.3: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
translation_text.mn11:8.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these two views’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re rid of greed, hate, delusion, craving, grasping, and ignorance. They don’t favor and oppose, and they enjoy non-proliferation.
translation_text.mn11:8.2: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
translation_text.mn11:8.3: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
translation_text.mn11:9.1: There are these four kinds of grasping.
translation_text.mn11:9.3: Grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
translation_text.mn11:10.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.
translation_text.mn11:10.2: But they don’t correctly describe the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.
translation_text.mn11:10.3: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, but not views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
translation_text.mn11:10.5: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these three things.
translation_text.mn11:10.6: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
translation_text.mn11:11.1: There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
translation_text.mn11:11.3: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures and views, but not precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
translation_text.mn11:11.5: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these two things.
translation_text.mn11:11.6: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
translation_text.mn11:12.1: There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
translation_text.mn11:12.3: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, and precepts and observances, but not theories of a self.
translation_text.mn11:12.5: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand this one thing.
translation_text.mn11:12.6: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
translation_text.mn11:13.1: In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be not rightly placed.
translation_text.mn11:13.4: and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be not rightly placed.
translation_text.mn11:13.6: It’s because that teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn11:14.1: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha claims to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.
translation_text.mn11:14.2: He describes the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
translation_text.mn11:15.1: In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be rightly placed.
translation_text.mn11:15.4: and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be rightly placed.
translation_text.mn11:15.6: It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn11:16.1: What is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of these four kinds of grasping?
translation_text.mn11:16.3: And what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of craving?
translation_text.mn11:16.5: And what is the source of feeling?
translation_text.mn11:16.7: And what is the source of contact?
translation_text.mn11:16.9: And what is the source of the six sense fields?
translation_text.mn11:16.11: And what is the source of name and form?
translation_text.mn11:16.13: And what is the source of consciousness?
translation_text.mn11:16.15: And what is the source of choices?
translation_text.mn11:17.1: When that mendicant has given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, with the fading away of ignorance and the arising of knowledge they don’t grasp at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, or theories of a self.
translation_text.mn11:17.2: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
translation_text.mn11:17.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
translation_text.mn11:17.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn11:17.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
